title: Self-reliance and materialism
prayerSummary: Pray for Japanese Christians and missionaries to demonstrate joyful dependency on God.
Pray for Japanese non-believers to see their limitations and need for God’s grace.
Pray for grace and salvation to become as prevalent in Japan as ganbatte and shōganai.
textBody:
There are two words you’re guaranteed to learn if you live in Japan:
Ganbatte—Do your best, keep going.
Shōganai—It can’t be helped, there’s nothing we can do.

Together these words demonstrate the spirit of self-reliance that is common in Japanese thinking. Most problems can be solved by simply trying harder. And the things that can’t be solved this way are seen as things that just need to be tolerated.
People work long hours to provide financial security for their families. Students study late into the night in order to pass entrance exams. They are relying on themselves to “do their best.”

In many ways this strong work ethic and determined perseverance is admirable. But without reliance on the merciful God who calls us to rest in him, it can lead to bitterness, burnout, and breakdowns—of individuals, families, and society.

Many Japanese apartments are filled with hard-earned comforts, but are empty of grace-filled relationships that give rest to the soul. And even missionaries need to keep a close watch on their hearts, that they don’t end up preaching at themselves “ganbatte!” and “shōganai!” rather than resting in the Lord and relying on his help.

photos.title: A student with her randoseru (standard elementary school backpack) and other bags, walking in Tokyo. It is common to see students commuting by themselves to school and after-school activities, even from a young age.
An elderly woman carrying multiple bags on her own. Being self-reliant is valued by both young and old.
An elementary school student studying on the train platform while waiting for her train.
Many students spend long hours studying after school, at libraries or juku (cram schools).
A mom with two children on a bicycle. It is common to see moms in urban areas transporting their children by bicycle; for example, to and from daycare or preschool.
Working professionals in Tokyo. It is expected that men persevere in working long hours at their companies.
An office building showing employees working even late into the night.

A display at the Toyota Kaikan Museum showing the company policy and last wishes of Sakichi Toyoda, the founder of the Toyota Group. The first one reads, "Always be faithful to your duties, thereby contributing to the Company and to the overall good."
By working hard, people hope to be able to provide for their families and to live without worry.
A man at a department store enjoying ice cream after work.
The Mitsukoshi flagship store in Nihombashi, the oldest and one of the finest department stores in Japan.
A customer intently trying out fountain pens at a stationery store. The quality of Japanese goods is well-known and trusted around the world.

Cute figurines used to rest one's chopsticks on. There are many shops that sell zakka (small, miscellaneous goods) which are well-made and bring delight to shoppers without necessarily being expensive.
Women lined up to enter a trendy fashion shop in Tokyo. It is common to see people willing to stand in long lines at popular shops and restaurants.

Daiso is a chain of over 3,600 hundred-yen shops across the country. Shops like this, which sell practical goods for as cheap as a hundred yen, became popular after the economic bubble burst in the 1990s.
Two young women washing their money at Zeniarai Benten shrine in Kamakura. It is said that the money washed at this shrine will multiply.
A woman buying a charm (omamori) at a temple in Tokyo. Owning an omamori can give people extra reassurance in their daily lives.
Examples of omamori, ranging from charms to help pass exams, to make wishes come true, to give good health, good fortune, and money.
